birds.name: American Robin
facts: American Robins are one of the first signs of spring and are known for their distinctive red-orange breast.
They can eat up to 14 feet of earthworms in a single day!
Robin eggs are famously blue, a color called 'robin egg blue.'

birds.name: Blue Jay
facts: Blue Jays are highly intelligent birds and can recognize individual humans.
They're excellent mimics and can imitate hawk calls to scare other birds away from feeders.
Blue Jays can carry acorns up to 150 miles away and bury them, helping oak trees spread.

birds.name: Cardinal
facts: Cardinals are one of the few bird species where both males and females sing.
The bright red male cardinals are more recognizable, but females are actually tan with reddish accents.
They mate for life and can raise up to three broods in a single breeding season.

birds.name: Chickadee
facts: Chickadees get their name from their distinctive 'chick-a-dee-dee-dee' call.
They have the ability to lower their body temperature at night to conserve energy.
Chickadees can remember thousands of hiding spots where they've cached seeds.

birds.name: Sparrow
facts: House Sparrows are found on every continent except Antarctica and are one of the most widespread bird species.
They're highly social and often gather in groups called 'charms' or 'quarrels.'
Male sparrows have a black bib that gets larger during breeding season to show dominance.

birds.name: Crow
facts: Crows are among the most intelligent birds and can solve complex puzzles.
They can recognize individual human faces and remember people who have treated them poorly.
Crows hold 'funerals' for dead crows and can hold grudges for years.

birds.name: Pigeon
facts: Pigeons can navigate using the Earth's magnetic field and have an incredible homing ability.
They were used as messengers in both World Wars and saved thousands of lives.
Pigeons can see ultraviolet light, which helps them find food and recognize other pigeons.

birds.name: Seagull
facts: Seagulls are highly adaptable birds that can drink both fresh and saltwater.
They're excellent problem-solvers and have learned to open chip bags and other food containers.
Seagulls communicate with each other using a complex system of calls and body language.

birds.name: Woodpecker
facts: Woodpeckers can peck up to 20 times per second without getting a headache thanks to special shock-absorbing tissues.
Their tongues are extremely long (sometimes longer than their heads) and coiled inside their skulls.
Woodpeckers don't sing; instead, they 'drum' on wood to communicate and establish territory.

birds.name: Owl
facts: Owls can rotate their heads up to 270 degrees, giving them nearly complete vision around them.
They have asymmetrical ears that help them locate prey by sound alone.
Most owl species are nocturnal hunters with eyesight that is about 100 times better than humans in low light.

birds.name: Scarlet Tanager
facts: Male Scarlet Tanagers are brilliant red with black wings, while females are yellow-green.
They migrate between South America and North America, traveling thousands of miles each year.
Scarlet Tanagers are insectivores and help control mosquito and other pest populations.

birds.name: Goldfinch
facts: American Goldfinches are the only finches that molt twice a year, changing colors dramatically.
In winter, they lose their bright yellow plumage and become a dull olive color.
Goldfinches have a special diet preference for thistle seeds and are attracted to nyjer feeders.

birds.name: Bluebird
facts: Eastern Bluebirds are cavity nesters and rely on nest boxes for breeding.
They were nearly driven to extinction but have made an amazing comeback thanks to conservation efforts.
Bluebirds are famous in folklore and are often considered symbols of happiness and hope.

birds.name: Hummingbird
facts: Hummingbirds are the only birds that can fly backwards and hover in mid-air.
Their wings beat up to 80 times per second, which creates the humming sound.
A hummingbird's heart can beat up to 1,260 times per minute, and they must eat every 10-15 minutes to survive.

birds.name: Kingfisher
facts: Kingfishers are expert hunters that can dive at speeds up to 25 mph to catch fish.
They have special adaptations in their eyes that let them see fish underwater without distortion.
Kingfishers nest in burrows they dig into riverbanks, creating tunnels up to 4 feet long.

birds.name: Toucan
facts: Toucans have massive, colorful beaks that can be up to one-third the length of their entire body.
Despite their size, toucan beaks are surprisingly light because they're mostly hollow.
Toucans use their beaks to regulate body temperature by controlling blood flow to the beak.

birds.name: Macaw
facts: Macaws are one of the most intelligent bird species and can live 50+ years in the wild.
They mate for life and are often seen flying in pairs or small flocks.
Macaws can eat seeds and nuts that are toxic to other animals because their digestive systems are specially adapted.

birds.name: Sunbird
facts: Sunbirds are tiny, jewel-like birds found in Africa, Asia, and Australia with iridescent plumage.
They have long curved beaks perfectly adapted for drinking nectar from flowers.
Sunbirds are often called 'African hummingbirds' because they fill a similar ecological niche.

birds.name: Bee-eater
facts: Bee-eaters are colorful birds that specialize in catching flying insects, including bees and wasps.
They can catch and eat hundreds of bees per day and are immune to most bee stings.
Bee-eaters are migratory birds and are known for their acrobatic flying displays.

birds.name: Roller
facts: Rollers get their name from their spectacular rolling and tumbling courtship displays in the air.
They have vibrant blue and green plumage and are found across Europe, Africa, and Asia.
Rollers are skilled hunters that catch insects and small lizards in mid-flight.

birds.name: Puffin
facts: Puffins have colorful beaks that brighten during breeding season and fade in winter.
They can hold multiple small fish in their beaks at once, sometimes up to 10 fish!
Puffins are excellent swimmers and use their wings to 'fly' underwater to catch fish.

birds.name: Kiwi
facts: Kiwis are flightless birds native to New Zealand and are the national bird of the country.
They have nostrils at the tip of their beaks, unique among birds, which helps them smell food in the ground.
Kiwi eggs are enormous relative to body sizeâ€”a kiwi egg can be up to 20% of the female's body weight!

birds.name: Secretary Bird
facts: Secretary Birds are unique raptors that hunt on the ground instead of from the air, walking up to 20 miles per day.
They stomp on prey with feet that can deliver kicks with over 500 pounds of force.
Secretary Birds got their name from the quill-like feathers on their heads that resemble quills secretaries once tucked behind their ears.

birds.name: Hoopoe
facts: Hoopoes have a spectacular crest of feathers on their heads that they raise when alarmed or excited.
They have long, slightly curved beaks that they use to probe into the ground for insects.
Hoopoes are found across Europe, Asia, and Africa and are featured in folklore and ancient texts.

birds.name: Lyrebird
facts: Lyrebirds are famous for their incredible mimicry abilities and can perfectly imitate other bird calls and even mechanical sounds.
They've been recorded imitating chainsaws, car alarms, camera shutters, and other human-made sounds.
Male lyrebirds have elaborate tail feathers shaped like a lyre, which they display during courtship dances.

birds.name: Waxwing
facts: Waxwings get their name from the waxy red tips on their wing feathers that resemble sealing wax.
They have a distinctive black mask across their eyes and a sharp crest on their heads.
Waxwings are highly social and travel in large flocks, sometimes in the hundreds.

birds.name: Nuthatch
facts: Nuthatches are unique birds that can walk headfirst down tree trunks, something most birds cannot do.
They get their name from their habit of wedging nuts into tree bark and 'hatching' them open with their beaks.
Nuthatches are acrobatic climbers and can rotate their feet 180 degrees to grip trees at different angles.
